author: Leicester Mercury
title: Leicester Mercury published Opinion: Brexit may hurt local economy
text:
Comments (0) 
I don't know if it's the passing of a few days, or that we've simply got use to momentous announcements from the corridors of power, but it feels like we can finally come up for air, writes Business Editor Tom Pegden. 
Britain has changed. as has our place on the global scene. 
The markets have slowed again after a brief rally last week following uncomfortable construction figures, and the pound is still weak against the euro. 
Things could look even worse when the Bank of England publishes its half-yearly assessment of risks to the financial system today. 
Chancellor George Osborne is talking of cutting corporation tax – who will end up paying for that tax cut I wonder – while interest rates look set to be cut even further to tackle the economic fall-out from Brexit. 
Who would want to be a saver these days? 
It doesn't matter how much the Eurosceptics tell us not to be negative, it's hard to put a brave face on it. 
And now it looks like tens of millions of euros destined to support Leicestershire businesses and create jobs and a green economy are set vanish into thin air (see page one). 
As with most things surrounding Brexit nobody really seems to know when the money will go, how much will actually go and what will replace it. 
But what is clear is we can't go on claiming European handouts if we're not going to be part of the European Union. 
The false claim that leaving the EU would save us £350 million a week that could go to the NHS tells us it's not just a case of stopping money flowing out of Britain and redirecting it to business – and other – causes at home. 
It's far more complex than that. 
Everyone keeps saying it, but it's hard to ignore the fact that business hates uncertainty. 
But Leicestershire's businesses are made of sterner stuff. 
The county economy weathered the last economic downturn better than some areas thanks to the variety of small and medium sized businesses here and the strength of its entrepreneurs and business leaders. 
Hopefully, Leicestershire won't take the hit so many fear.
